title-group.article-title: Unusual matrine-adenine hybrids isolated from Sophora davidii and their inhibitory effects on human cytomegalovirus

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Unusual matrine–adenine hybrids isolated from
Sophora davidii
and their inhibitory effects on human cytomegalovirus

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Zhi-Jun Zhang 1 , Shu-Wei Dong 1 , Dan-Dan Gao, Xin-Ye Du, Yan-Qing Xie, Xue-Shan Xia,
Rong-Tao Li *

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Faculty of Life Science and Technology, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, 650500, China

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Edible flowers
Alkaloids
Matrine–adenine hybrids
Anti- human cytomegalovirus
A B S T R A C T

A phytochemical investigation on the flowers of
Sophora davidii
resulted in the isolation of three unusual matrine–adenine hybrids, sophovicines A–C, together with biogenetically related analogue sophocarpine. Their structures and absolute configurations were determined by NMR analysis, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and electronic circular dichroism (ECD) data. Since sophovicines represent the first example of matrine-adenine hybrids, a putative biosynthetic pathway toward sophovicines A–C was proposed. In addition, computational molecular modeling suggested that compounds sophovicines B and C may have potent activities against human cytomegalovirus (HCMV). So, the inhibit effects of isolates on HCMV were evaluated. The results show that sophovicines B and C can inhibit HCMV replication effectively with IC 50 values of 7.12 and 7.32 μ M, respectively.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
Orphanage
sec.p: * Corresponding author.

sec.p: E-mail address: rongtaolikm@163.com (R.-T. Li).

sec.p: 1 These authors contributed equally to this work.

sec.title: 2.1. Isolation and structure elucidation
sec.p:
The dried flowers of
S. davidii
were extracted with EtOH/H 2 O (95:5) at room temperature three times. The extract was partitioned between 1.0‰ HCl/H 2 O and EtOAc. Then, the water-soluble materials were adjusted to pH 10 with saturated Na 2 CO 3 aq, were extracted with CHCl 3 to obtained crude alkaloid. Fractionation and purification of the crude alkaloid by column chromatography (CC) over MCI, silica gel, reversedphase silica gel, and Sephadex LH-20 afforded three unusual matrine-–adenine hybrids, named sophovicines A–C (1–3), as well as biogenetically related compound sophocarpine (4) (
).

Sophovicine A (1), obtained as colorless needles crystals (toluene–methanol, 9:1). The molecular formula of 1 was determined to be C 20 H 27 N 7 O with eleven degrees of unsaturation based on the HRESIMS data at m/z 404.2168 [M+ Na] + (calcd for 404.2169). IR absorptions implied the presence of lactam carbonyl group ( 1641 cm 1 ). The 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ) exhibited signals of two olefinic protons ( δ H 8.06 and 8.11) and four deshielded aliphatic proton signals ( δ H 5.17, 4.15, 4.11, and 3.22). The 13 C NMR ( Table 1 ) and the HSQC spectra revealed the existence of 20 carbons due to one lactam carbonyl group ( δ C 167.0), two sp 2 methines ( δ C 142.8 and 153.5), three sp 2 quaternary carbons ( δ C 120.1, 150.9, and 157.1), and 14 sp 3 carbons including nine methylenes and five methines ( δ C 37.6, 40.9, 55.3, 56.9, and 65.8).

The relative configuration of 1 was assigned by a ROESY spectrum, in which the correlations H-5/H-12 b, H-6/H-12 b, H-7/H-12 b, H-8a/H-17 b, H-17 b/H-11, and H-11/H-14 suggested that H-5, H-6, and H-7 ( Fig. 3 ) were in the same orientations, whereas H-11 and H-14 were on the same face. The absolute configuration of 1 was confirmed by the single X-ray diffraction experiment. Qualified crystals of 1 were acquired by recrystallization in toluene/methanol (9:1), which obtained a successful performance of X-ray crystallography by using graphitemono-chromated Cu K α radiation ( λ = 1.54178 A). It not only exhibited the unique structure of matrine–adenine hybrids in 1 as revealed by spectroscopic data analysis, but also determined its absolute configurations of C-5, C-6, C-7, C-11, and C-14 as (5 S , 6 S , 7 R , 11 R , 14 R ) ( Fig. 4 ).

Sophovicine B (2), obtained as white amorphous powder, exhibited an [M+ Na] + ion peak at m/z 404.2168 in its positive HRESIMS, which was consistent with the molecular formula C 20 H 27 N 7 O with 11 degrees of unsaturation. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data of 2 ( Table 1 ) together with the HSQC spectrum revealed the presence of 20 carbon signals. Comparison of 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 2 with those of 1 revealed that the structure of 2 was similar to that of 1. The main difference between them was reflected in the chemical shifts of C-11 ( δ C 55.3 (d) in 1; 50.4 (d) in 2), C-12 ( δ C 22.5 (t) in 1; 30.6 (t) in 2), C-13 ( δ C 27.6 (t) in 1; 47.0 (d) in 2), and C-14 ( δ C 56.9 (d) in 1; 37.3 (t) in 2). These differences suggested that the matrine and adenine units were connected by the bond between C-13 and N-9’. This hypothesis was further supported by the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlation peaks of H 2 -12/H-13/ H 2 -14 and HMBC correlations between H-13 and C-11, C-12, C-14, C-4 ′ , and C-8’. By comparing the 1 H NMR spectral data and ROESY correlations, the relative configuration of matrine unit of 2 was similar as 1, this means H-5, H-6, H-7 were α -oriented and H-11 was β -oriented. The H-13 was β -oriented, which was determined by ROESY correlation of H-11/H-13.

The absolute configuration of compound 2 was confirmed by comparison of calculated and experimental ECD spectra ( Fig. 5 ). The experimental spectrum of 2 exhibited positive Cotton effect (CE) at 215 nm , and negative CE at 260 nm , which agreed with the calculated spectrum of the (5 S , 6 S , 7 R , 11 R , 13 R ) enantiomer. Therefore, the structure of 2 was final elucidated, and named as sophovicine B.

Sophovicine C (3), obtained as white amorphous powder. The molecular formula of C 20 H 27 N 7 O 2 as determined by the HRESIMS ( m/z 396.2156 [M-H] - , calcd for C 20 H 26 N 7 O
2 m
/z 396.2153), 16 mass units higher than that of 2. The UV and IR spectra of 3 revealed characteristic absorptions similar to those of 2. Interpretation of the 2D NMR data of 3 demonstrated that it was the N -1 oxide of 2, which was confirmed by the characteristic downfield NMR shifts of C-3 ( δ C 69.8), C-6 ( δ C 67.9), and C-10 ( δ C 69.6). In addition, the experimental ECD spectrum of 3 showed the same CE as 2, manifesting that the absolute configuration of 3 was identical to that of 2.
2.2. Proposed biosynthesis pathways

Based on the co-isolated major alkaloid sophocarpine (4) from the same plant material. At first, we thought that the isolated compounds 2 and 3 with β -substituted adenine may be derived from 4 and adenine through a Michael addition. Unfortunately, none of the desired compound was detected albeit some efforts using basic or acidic conditions had been made. Given compound 1 had an α -substituted adenine, another hypothetical biogenetic pathway of 1–3 involved epoxidation of 4 was proposed as shown in Fig. 6 . Namely, starting from the epoxide intermediate i, the 13,14-epoxy ring was subsequently opened by adenine through path a and b to form intermediates ii and iii, respectively. Then, intermediates ii and iii could be further reduced to give 1 and 2, respectively. Certainly, compound 2 was further oxidation to yield 3.
2.3. Molecular docking investigation

sec.title: 2.4. Inhibitory effects on HCMV
sec.p: Based on the results of molecular docking, compounds 1–4 were evaluated for their inhibition on HCMV, and ganciclovir was used as positive control (IC 50 = 5.28 μ M). Among them, compounds 2 and 3 can inhibit HCMV replication effectively with IC 50 values of 7.12 and 7.32 μ M, respectively ( Table 2 ).

sec.title: 2.5. SAR analysis
sec.p: On the basis of the structural features of the isolates and their anti-HCMV activity, brief structure-activity relationships were analyzed. According to biological results, matrine–adenine hybrids between C-13 and N-9’ (2 and 3) are active. But matrine–adenine hybrids between C-14 and N-9’ (1) or matrine-type alkaloid (4) are inactive. In addition, no obvious differences will be caused by whether the N -1 atom of matrine unit is oxidized or not.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Ganciclovir was used as positive control.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: b IC: 50% inhibitory concentration. (Mean ± SD of 3 tests).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 50 c TC: 50% toxic concentration. (Mean ± SD of 3 tests).

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p:
In summary, three matrine–adenine hybrids, named sophovicines A–C (1–3), together with biogenetically related compound sophocarpine (4), were isolated from the flowers of
S. davidii
. The structures and absolute configurations of new compounds were elucidated by extensive spectroscopic techniques, X-ray diffraction analysis, along with the experimental and calculated electronic circular dichroism (ECD). Since new compounds represent the first example of matrine-adenine hybrids, a possible biosynthetic pathway for 1–3 was proposed. In addition, all the isolates were evaluated for their inhibition on HCMV. Among them, compounds 2 and 3 can inhibit HCMV replication effectively with IC 50 values of 7.12 and 7.32 μ M, respectively. Moreover, brief structure-activity relationships were analyzed. This discovery not only extends the chemical diversity of natural alkaloids, but also could be extremely meaningful to the discovery of new anti-HCMV drugs. Meanwhile, these novel structures might give some insight into new leading heterocyclic compounds for the development of related drugs, while further investigations such as synthetic effort and in-depth biological testing are really needed.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: UV, Shimadzu UV-2401 A spectrophotometer; Optical rotations, Jasco DIP-370 digital polarimeter; IR, Tenor 27 spectrophotometer; 1D and 2D-NMR, Bruker AVANCE III-600 spectrometer; HRESIMS, Agilent 6530Q of spectrometer; medium-pressure liquid chromatography (MPLC), Büchi Labortechnik AG CH-9230 Flawil; Silica gel, Qingdao Marine Chemical Factory; sephadex LH-20; mersham Biosciences AB; column, Soochow high tech chromatography CO., Ltd.; ODS-C 18 , YMC Co., Ltd.; precoated silica gel plates, Qingdao Marine Chemical Factory.

sec.title: 4.2. Plant material
sec.p:
The flowers of
Sophora davidii (Franch.) Pavol. (Fabaceae)
were collected Honghe county , Yunnan Province , China (
N23 ◦ 59 ′
,
E103 ◦ 41 ′
), in
August 2019
, and identified by Dr. Xuan-Qin Chen. A voucher specimen (number: KUMST20190818) has been deposited at the Key Laboratory of Phytochemistry ( Kunming University of Science and Technology )
.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p:
Dried flowers of
S. davidii
( 5 kg ) were powered and extracted with EtOH/H 2 O (95:5, 24 h × 3) at room temperature, the extract was partitioned between 1.0‰ HCl/H 2 O and EtOAc. Then, the water-soluble materials were adjusted to pH 10 with saturated Na 2 CO 3 aq, were extracted with CHCl 3 to obtained crude alkaloid ( 18 g ). The crude alkaloid was subjected to basic alumina CC eluting with a gradient of petroleum ether EtOAc system (20:1 → 1:1) adjusted by diethylamine (5‰) to afford five fractions A-E. Fraction A ( 5.8 g ) was further separated by silica gel CC (petroleum ether acetone diethylamine, 85:15:0.5) to yield three subfractions A01-03. Fraction A02 ( 2.3 g ) was further subjected to silica gel CC (EtOAc MeOH, 40:1) to yield 4 ( 458.6 mg ). Fraction B ( 3.6 g ) was further separated by silica gel CC (petroleum ether acetone diethylamine, 70:30:0.5) to obtained six subfractions B01-06. Fraction B03 ( 815 mg ) was further purified by a silica gel CC (CHCl 3 –MeOH, 30:1) to afford compound 3 ( 6.2 mg ). Fraction B06 ( 460 mg ) was separated by silica gel CC (EtOAc MeOH, 40:1) to yield 2 ( 4.6 mg ). Fraction C ( 3.2 g ) was further purified by a silica gel CC (CHCl 3 –MeOH, 10:1) and Sephadex LH-20 (CHCl 3 –MeOH, 1:1) to afford four subfractions C01-04. Fraction C01 ( 260 mg ) was chromatographed over repeated silica gel CC (CHCl 3 –MeOH–H 2 O, 40:10:0.1) to yield 1 ( 8.2 mg ).

sec.title: 4.4.1. Sophovicine A (1)
sec.p: Colorless crystals (toluene–methanol, 9:1); mp 189.5–190.5 ◦ C; 24

sec.title: 4.4.2. Sophovicine B (2)

White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 24 + 61 ( c 0.10, CH 3 OH); UV ( CH 3 OH) λ
ma x
(log ε ): 196 (4.58), 261 (4.20) nm; ECD ( c 3.15 × 10 4 M, MeOH), λ
ma x

sec.p:
White amorphous powder; [ α ] D 24 + 27 ( c 0.12, CH 3 OH); UV ( CH 3 OH) λ
ma x
(log ε ): 196 (4.61), 261 (4.23) nm; ECD ( c 5.74 × 10 4 M, MeOH), λ

sec.title: 4.4.4. Crystallographic data for compound 1
sec.p:
C 20 H 27 N 7 O, M = 381.48, a = 7.7400(2) Å, b = 8.0194(2) Å, c = 30.4457(8) Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 90 ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 1889.77(8) Å 3 , T = 100.(2) K, space group P 212121 , Z = 4, μ (Cu Kα) = 0.705 mm 1 , 18,368 reflections measured, 3717 independent reflections (
Rint
= 0.0552). The final
R 1
values were 0.0551 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.1462 (
I >
2 σ ( I )). The final
R 1
values were 0.0553 (all data). The final wR ( F 2 ) values were 0.1463 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.119. Flack parameter = 0.20(8). The crystallographic data for 1 has been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (no. 2022229).

sec.title: 4.5. ECD calculation
sec.p:
The methods for ECD calculation were performed according to previous work (
).

sec.title: 4.6. Molecular modeling
sec.p:
Discovery Studio was used to carry out molecular docking studies using recently published methods (
).

sec.title: 4.7. Biological assay
sec.p: Cytotoxicity assay: The cytotoxic effects of candidate reagents on HRT-18 and HFF cells were evaluated by methylthiazolyldiphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay. Briefly, monolayer of cells grown in 96-well plates was incubated with indicated concentrations of reagents. After 48 h, the cells were stained with MTT solution at 0.5 mg /mL for 4 h. The supernatants were removed and the cells were added with the formed formazan crystals dissolved in 200 μ L DMSO. The absorbance at 490 nm was determined by using Multiskan GO Microplate Spectrophotometer. (Thermo Fisher, USA ). The 50% cytotoxic concentration (CC 50 ) was calculated by the GraphPad Prism 8.0 software.

Cytopathic effect (CPE) inhibition assay: Cell monolayers were grown in 96-well plates. The HRT-18 cell monolayers were inoculated with 100 TCID 50 of the VR-1558 strain of HCoV-OC43 at 34 ◦ C for 2 h, and the HFF cell monolayers were inoculated with HCMV with a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 1 at 37 ◦ C for 2 h. The inoculum was then removed and the cells were treated with indicated concentrations of reagents. When 75% or more of the infected cells showed CPE under the microscope, the inhibition effect was evaluated by MTT assay as mentioned above. The 50% inhibition concentration (IC 50 ) was then calculated by the GraphPad Prism 8.0 software.
Declaration of competing interest
